content: The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes certain improvements in the earned income tax credit permanent, including strengthening the credit for individuals with no qualifying children, allowing the credit in case of certain separated spouses, and eliminating the disqualified investment income test. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes permanent the increase in the credit percentage for individuals with three or more qualifying children under Section 32(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit percentage for 3 or more qualifying children is set at 45% with a phaseout percentage of 21.06%. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" makes permanent the reduction of marriage penalty by increasing the phaseout amount for joint returns by $5,000. This amount will be adjusted for inflation after 2014. The amendments made by the "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" include substituting 'calendar year 2009' for 'calendar year 1992' in subparagraph (B) and a conforming amendment to Section 32(b) by striking paragraph (3). These changes will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being strengthened for individuals with no qualifying children. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced for individuals over 21 but under 25 who are not full-time students. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced for individuals over 21 but under 25 who are not full-time students. An individual is considered a full-time student if carrying more than half the normal full-time workload for their course of study. The Secretary of the Treasury will develop procedures to verify claims for the credit against information returns related to higher education expenses. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage are increased to 15.3%. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced for individuals over 21 but under 25 who are not full-time students. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage are increased to 15.3%. Amendments are made to the earned income amount and phaseout amount in the tax code. The amendments made by this section, substituting 'calendar year 2012' for 'calendar year 1992' in the tax code, will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Taxpayer eligible for credit for individuals with no qualifying children if qualifying children do not have valid social security numbers. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals with qualifying children who do not have valid social security numbers to still be eligible for the tax credit. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. Additionally, a credit is allowed for separated spouses in certain cases. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a special rule for separated spouses regarding tax filing status. An individual can be considered unmarried for tax purposes if they file separately, live with a qualifying child for more than half the year, and meet certain residency conditions. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act, allowing separated spouses to file taxes as unmarried if they live with a qualifying child for more than half the year. Taxpayers can claim a tax credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. Taxpayers can claim a tax credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. This allows the other family member to be treated as an eligible individual without a qualifying child for tax purposes. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment date and allows a qualifying child to be claimed by a parent, preventing other custodial parents from claiming the child. SEC. 7. ELIMINATION OF DISQUALIFIED INVESTMENT INCOME TEST. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by removing subsection (i) of Section 32. Conforming amendments are made to other sections of the Code. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
